commentary:
It is important to know the type of love Paul is talking about in 1 Corinthians 13. The ancient Greek had four words for love: 1.) Eros — this refers to romantic love. 2.) Storge — this describes family love, i.e. the love between a parent and a child. 3.) Philia — Brotherly friendship and affection. It is the love between friends. All three types of love are innate to human nature. Thus you do not have to be a child of God to have them. Even publicans have philia love (see Matthew 5:46).
The fourth type of love, Agape, is not innate to human nature. It comes only from God . This is a self-sacrificing love. It is not an emotion but a principle that guides us to choose kindness towards everyone, including the unlovable. This is the love Paul is talking about in this chapter. Driven by this love, Jesus and Stephen prayed for those who persecuted them (see Luke 23:34; Acts 7:60). To be acceptable to God, our deeds must be driven by Agape love (see 2 Corinthians 5:14).

author.name: Prayer:
author.position: Father, grant us the grace to surrender to Your will and cultivate Agape love, that it may be the driving force behind all our actions for You.
